claim: Exactly 75 account holders in South Bohemia still do not own credit cards.
extra_info: A3 contains the region names; South Bohemia is one of region names.
reasoning: The claim states exactly 75 account holders in South Bohemia do not own credit cards. The card table has types gold/classic/junior (no explicit 'credit' type). Interpreting 'credit cards' as all cards in the card table: there are 370 accounts in South Bohemia, of which 296 have no card; or 445 disposition holders (account holders), of which 371 have no card. No standard interpretation of 'account holders without credit cards' yields 75. The number 75 only corresponds to the count of DISPONENT-type disposition holders in South Bohemia (all of whom lack cards), but the claim does not restrict to DISPONENTs. The claim of 75 is contradicted by the data.

content.text:
Now I understand the schema. The claim is about "account holders" in South Bohemia who don't have credit cards. Let me trace the relationships:
- `district.A3` = region name (South Bohemia)
- `account.district_id` → `district.district_id`
- `disp` links accounts to clients (and cards link via `disp_id`)
- `card.type` = 'credit' for credit cards

The claim says "account holders" — I'll interpret this as accounts in South Bohemia that have no associated credit card. Let me query this.

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "SELECT DISTINCT A3 FROM district WHERE A3 LIKE '%Bohemia%';"
input.description: Check region name for South Bohemia

content.content:
central Bohemia
south Bohemia
west Bohemia
north Bohemia
east Bohemia

tool_use_result.stdout:
central Bohemia
south Bohemia
west Bohemia
north Bohemia
east Bohemia

content.text: The region is "south Bohemia" (lowercase). Now let me count account holders (accounts) in South Bohemia that don't have credit cards.

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM account a
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND a.account_id NOT IN (
    SELECT DISTINCT disp.account_id
    FROM disp
    JOIN card ON card.disp_id = disp.disp_id
    WHERE card.type = 'credit'
);
"
input.description: Count accounts in South Bohemia without credit cards

content.text: That gives 370 accounts. But the claim says "account holders" which could mean individual clients/dispositions rather than accounts. Let me also check by counting dispositions (account holders linked to accounts).

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (
    SELECT disp_id FROM card WHERE type = 'credit'
);
"
input.description: Count disp entries in South Bohemia without credit cards

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Count clients in South Bohemia without any credit card
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM client c
JOIN disp dp ON c.client_id = dp.client_id
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND c.client_id NOT IN (
    SELECT dp2.client_id
    FROM disp dp2
    JOIN card ON card.disp_id = dp2.disp_id
    WHERE card.type = 'credit'
);
"
input.description: Count clients in South Bohemia without credit cards

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Also try: account holders without ANY card (not just credit)
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM account a
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND a.account_id NOT IN (
    SELECT DISTINCT disp.account_id
    FROM disp
    JOIN card ON card.disp_id = disp.disp_id
);
"
input.description: Count accounts in South Bohemia without any card

content.text: Let me also try counting just the "OWNER" type dispositions (primary account holders):

SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND dp.type = 'OWNER'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (

);
"
input.description: Count OWNER disp in South Bohemia without credit cards

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Try without any card type filter - just 'card' table

FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND dp.type = 'OWNER'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (

input.description: Count OWNER disps in South Bohemia without any card

content.text: Let me also check total counts to validate:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Total accounts in South Bohemia
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM account a JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia';
"
input.description: Total accounts in South Bohemia

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Check card types
SELECT DISTINCT type FROM card;
"
input.description: List card types

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Check if 75 matches anything: accounts with credit cards in South Bohemia
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT a.account_id)
FROM account a
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
JOIN disp dp ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN card c ON c.disp_id = dp.disp_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia' AND c.type = 'credit';
"
input.description: Count accounts with credit cards in South Bohemia

content.text:
Interesting! The card types are "gold", "classic", "junior" — there is no "credit" type in the card table. The card table tracks card types as gold/classic/junior, not credit/debit. However, the claim mentions "credit cards" — this could refer to all cards in the `card` table (since in banking context, these are all types of credit cards).

Let me check if interpreting "credit cards" as any card gives us 75:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Accounts in South Bohemia WITH any card
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT a.account_id)
FROM account a
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
JOIN disp dp ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN card c ON c.disp_id = dp.disp_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia';
"
input.description: Accounts in South Bohemia with any card

content.text: So 74 accounts have cards, 370 total, meaning 296 don't have cards. That doesn't match 75 either.

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "

SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
JOIN card c ON c.disp_id = dp.disp_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia';

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- OWNER disp with cards in South Bohemia
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id

JOIN card c ON c.disp_id = dp.disp_id

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- DISPONENT disp without cards in South Bohemia
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia' AND dp.type = 'DISPONENT'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (SELECT disp_id FROM card);
"
input.description: DISPONENT without cards in South Bohemia

content.text:
There it is! 75 DISPONENT (non-owner) account holders in South Bohemia who don't have cards. But wait — the claim says "account holders" which typically means the primary account owner. Let me reconsider the claim: "Exactly 75 account holders in South Bohemia still do not own credit cards."

The term "account holders" could refer to anyone with a disposition entry (OWNER or DISPONENT). Let me check if there's a reading where 75 is the right answer more naturally:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Total DISPONENT in South Bohemia
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia' AND dp.type = 'DISPONENT';
"
input.description: Total DISPONENT in South Bohemia

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- Maybe client-level, clients in South Bohemia without cards
-- Using client table
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT c.client_id)
FROM client c
JOIN district d ON c.district_id = d.district_id
JOIN disp dp ON dp.client_id = c.client_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (SELECT disp_id FROM card);
"
input.description: Clients in South Bohemia without cards

content.text: There are exactly 75 DISPONENT account holders in South Bohemia total. And all 75 of them don't have cards. Let me verify the client-based approach more carefully — the hint says A3 is a region in the district table, and the account is linked to district. Let me check if clients also have a district_id:

content.text: Clients have their own district_id. The claim refers to "account holders in South Bohemia" — using the account's district (not client's district) is most natural since accounts are in districts. Let me re-query with account-based South Bohemia mapping:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/financial.sqlite" "
-- account holders = all disp entries for accounts in South Bohemia, without any card
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM disp dp
JOIN account a ON dp.account_id = a.account_id
JOIN district d ON a.district_id = d.district_id
WHERE d.A3 = 'south Bohemia'
AND dp.disp_id NOT IN (SELECT disp_id FROM card);
"
input.description: All account holders without cards in South Bohemia (via account district)

content.text:
That's 371. But using DISPONENT only gives 75, and total DISPONENTs is also 75, meaning none of them have cards.

The most natural interpretation: "account holders" = people associated with accounts (via disp) in South Bohemia. That gives 371 without cards, not 75. However, 75 is the count of DISPONENT-type holders without cards. But the claim doesn't specify DISPONENT.

Let me check one more interpretation: maybe "credit card" is literally a card type and in this database, classic/junior/gold are all the types. The number 75 doesn't match any of the natural interpretations of "all account holders without credit cards" (370 accounts, 371 or 445 disps, 296 accounts without any card).

The closest match to 75 is DISPONENT holders in South Bohemia (total 75, none with cards). But the claim is about "account holders" generically, which should include all people (OWNERs and DISPONENTs).

None of the standard interpretations of "account holders in South Bohemia who do not own credit cards" yields exactly 75. The number 75 only appears for a very specific subgroup (DISPONENT-type only). The claim says 75, but the data shows either 296, 370, 371, or 445 depending on interpretation — none of which equal 75.
